item.title: Cory add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "Give every man thine ear, but few thy voice; Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Cory add a quote by William Shakespear
item.description: "There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so." -- William Shakespear

item.title: Cory add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "We know what we are, but not what we may be." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Cory add a quote by Samuel Beckett
item.description: "Dance first. Think later. It's the natural order." -- Samuel Beckett

item.title: Cory add a quote by Rene Descartes
item.description: "For I found myself embarrassed with so many doubts and errors that it seemed to me that the effort to instruct myself had no effect other than the increasing discovery of my own ignorance" -- Rene Descartes

item.title: Cory add a quote by Barbara Kingsolver
item.description: "Back then I was still appalled that God would set down his barefoot boy and girl dollies into an Eden where, presumably, He had just turned loose elephantiasis and microes that eat the human cornea. Now I understand, God is not just rooting fo the dollies." -- Barbara Kingsolver

item.title: Cory add a quote by Marcus Tullius Cicero
item.description: "A room without books is like a body without a soul." -- Marcus Tullius Cicero

item.title: Cory add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "My words fly up, my thoughts remain below: Words without thoughts never to heaven go." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Cory add a quote by James Madison
item.description: "You must first enable the government to control the governed; and in the next place, oblige it to control itself." -- James Madison

item.title: Cory add a quote by SHAKESPEARE WILLIAM
item.description: "You have her father's love, Demetrius; Let me have Hermia's: do you marry him." -- SHAKESPEARE WILLIAM

item.title: Cory add a quote by Voltaire
item.description: "Optimism," said Cacambo, "What is that?" "Alas!" replied Candide, "It is the obstinacy of maintaining that everything is best when it is worst." -- Voltaire

item.title: Cory add a quote by Fyodor Dostoevsky
item.description: "Although Pulcheria Alexandrovna was forty-three, she still showed traces of her former beauty and seemed much younger than her years. This is generally true of women who remain serene in spirit, fresh in their impressions, and spontaneously warmhearted right to the edge of old age. One might add that in this way, and only in this way, they retain their beauty in old age too." -- Fyodor Dostoevsky

item.title: Cory add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "To die, to sleep - To sleep, perchance to dream - ay, there's the rub, For in this sleep of death what dreams may come..." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Cory add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "Most true is it that 'beauty is in the eye of the gazer.' My master’s colourless, olive face, square, massive brow, broad and jetty eyebrows, deep eyes, strong features, firm, grim mouth, — all energy, decision, will, — were not beautiful, according to rule; but they were more than beautiful to me; they were full of an interest, an influence that quite mastered me, — that took my feelings from my own power and fettered them in his. I had not intended to love him; the reader knows I had wrought hard to extirpate from my soul the germs of love there detected; and now, at the first renewed view of him, they spontaneously arrived, green and strong! He made me love him without looking at me." -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Cory add a quote by Tana French
item.description: "What I am telling you, before you begin my story, is this -- two things: I crave truth. And I lie. " -- Tana French

item.title: Cory add a quote by Sheri Holman
item.description: "Good and Evil are opposite points on a circle, Dr. Chiver. Greater good is just halfway back to Bad." -- Sheri Holman

item.title: Cory add a quote by Edith Wharton
item.description: "An unalterable and unquestioned law of the musical world required that the German text of French operas sung by Swedish artists should be translated into Italian for the clearer understanding of English-speaking audiences." -- Edith Wharton
